Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD committed an unreasonable error in concluding the applicant was not a 'person in need of protection' under IRPA
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution due to past attacks and her status as a woman in Haiti
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision upheld; asylum claim rejected
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on gender and past attacks
Assessment_Factor: Fear linked to Convention grounds, personal risk vs. generalized risk
Procedural_Issue: Review of administrative decision by Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing generalized crime in Haiti affecting all genders
Application_Basis: Claim of gender-based persecution and past harm
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of evidence linking fear to gender-based persecution or Convention grounds
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection
Governing_Rule: A person must demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds to qualify as a person in need of protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove personal risk or persecution tied to Convention grounds
Outcome: Asylum claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Harm_Assessment: Risk from generalized violence in Haiti, not specific persecution
Cause_Description: Applicant sought asylum due to fear of persecution from past attacks and gender, but RPD found no link to protected grounds
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court assessed whether RPDâ€™s evaluation of evidence was reasonable
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient evidence to establish gender-based persecution
Evidence_Assessment: RPD reasonably concluded that fear stemmed from general instability, not targeted persecution
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to demonstrate a personal risk distinct from general conditions in Haiti
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of specific evidence connecting harm to Convention grounds
